A core question is probably whether it makes more sense to have a very complex, general-purpose robot, or have a whole bunch of very specialized robots. The more I think about it, the generalized approach could be really powerful. But where I have serious doubts is whether there's any real for that generalized device to be in the form of a human body. Wouldn't it make much more sense for the robot to have a highly adaptable shape, in particular with a variable number and type of appendages? Hans Moravec, I think, was promoting the idea of a "robot bush" a few decades ago. I'm sure that idea is still being seriously pursued, and maybe has been taken a lot farther since then. Where does it stand now?

AI development will create the possibility of the general purpose humanoid robot. This will likely create the societal condition of plenty rather than scarcity. In the spectrum of human capability, there are vast differences in potential contribution to society by individuals. If general purpose humanoid robots can do everything that the ‚Äúless capable‚Äù segment of humanity can contribute, what is the alternative? Will the product of robots in service or manufacturing be somehow available to individuals? Will those with the capacity to innovate in a way that humanoid robots cannot be compensated in a different way? Will some people elect a life of leisure while others work? In a free, market-based society, value is added whenever labor and materials are combined to create a new product or service. If a large proportion of the population is no longer required to participate directly to achieve this level of plenty, how DO they participate? I guess we need some more sci-fi authors to ponder‚Ä¶

I like the sustainable energy future. Thing is, on a program I watched by some expert, some of the materials used in making these batteries, has to be done by massive strip mining of the planet. Not by drilling..or going underground, but  stripping the surface of parts of the planet. Mountains, hills, forestry etc. This way of mining could poison rivers and lakes. I mention this because as a child, I am now 72, I watched as our local countryside was devastated by strip mining for coal. Afterwards, when mining was finished and the massive creator was filled in, what was left behind was ugly. No rolling hills or grassland as it once was, but a gray, flat, ugliness. Those that came after me, would have thought it was always so...but it wasn't. We used to pick-nick, and have adventures amongst its previous beauty. All kinds of birds, insects, including beautiful dragon flies, frogs, newts, rabbits and hare's. Why is it that to give humans a cleaner future, we first have to destroy nature. Destroy natural beauty? I know things have to change to make way for cleaner energy,.but do we have to destroy nature's natural beauty along the way ? Will what we end up with, be worth it in the end ? Ugly wind turbines spoiling the horizon, and the terrible scars of strip mining ? Not to mention the effects it all has on wildlife. I am glad I am old..I won't be around to see it..I mean that. Maybe I am unknowingly exaggerating it..I truly hope so.

Self-driving stumbled on the mathematical dichotomy between digital fractional computing versus the old analog instantaneous sensory technologies. We went totally digital in the 1970's with the alpha chip and never looked back until now. We essentially abandoned analog circuitry. We were so analog committed prior to that time that Apollo 11, the first Moon landing, was accomplished using almost all analog.circuitry with the exception of switching diodes. Transistors were commercially in their infancy, and ICs hadn't been invented yet.

The big question to ask Elon is will SpaceX be the primary booster for everyone to get to orbit.  Thousand of reusable boosters sitting around waiting for the 2 year window to get to Mars. It can be launching every thing to space for ULA, Blue Origin and ESA and anyone else. The most expensive part of every space launch can be solved with SpaceX boosters.  For example the Falcon 9 upper stage represent about about 20% of it's hardware cost. If booster service is done by Starliner and that cost of launch is under $1 million then in theory a Falcon 9 upper stage launch can be done for under $15 million.  Assuming everyone else is not as efficient a Falcon 9 it would at least meant all launches done with Starliner boost can be 1/3 the cost if they use Starliner for boosting services.

Predictions - mindset is very cool. I never thought of it until now. It makes my thinking more focused. Especially predictions in numbers. What is the likelihood that I will finish my master's thesis? Let's say it's 80 % (assuming based on a guessed dropout rate of 20%). The luck is still on my side. Let's say I would drop my other goals and be able to  focus on the thesis, what is the likelihood that I will do it in 6 months? I would say maybe 85% - you know some life events could still happen. What about in 8 months + with the help of supervisors? I would say 95% because I could argue that most people with good supervisor relationship end up being very engaged in the process. Even though this is guess work, it's kind of motivating! I can now go around saying that it's most likely that at least in 8 months I will have done a sccesfully finished master's thesis! I mean, it's not that special. But on the other hand, if I let myself slip, I end up being one of the 20% who don't get their master's thesis done even in 2 or 3 years who end up dropping out. If I go the other route of increasing my distractions and negative emotions and staying away from the supporting superwisors because of embarrassment or fear of showing how badly I'm doing.

Elon, if you read this, I think that you are mistaken on two things. First, nations now will place a much greater emphasis on nuclear power than they world before the UK and the USA reneged upon their commitment to defend Ukraine. I strongly support nuclear energy because we need nuclear technology to go space. Wind and solar energy technology will not achieve that objective. That acknowledged, nations will want nuclear power for nuclear weapons because they cannot now rely upon the great powers to honor their commitment to defend weaker nations. Second, a battery with a large energy density is, (by definition), a bomb. In a world in which small nations seek weapons to defend themselves against big nations, batteries with a large energy density (if developed), WILL be used as bombs.  Instead, we need a thing that will produce the relatively small amounts of electrical energy that we need when we need that energy. We have had that technology for about 50 years. It does not consume fuel. It is environmentally friendly. It is compact. It can be scaled to be large or small in size and in power. It is well proven technology. It is inexpensive. We have only to decide to use that technology.

"every high quality minute of thinking is a million dollars"  First off, if Elon was some greedy CEO like so many people try to frame him as, he wouldn't be giving a 60 min interview for less than 60 millions dollars. The fact that he's doing it for free, is pretty nice of him. How many other CEOs would give up 60 million to share information with us? And, let's think about that in terms of production capability... the most I've ever been able to produce, thus far, is 3 dollars per minute. Someone working a $20/hour job is producing .33 dollars per minute. That's means my minute is worth 9 times much as their minute in terms of producing or accomplishing a task. And that means Elon's minute is worth 333,333 times as much as mine. Now, I don't believe these are absolute indicators of a person's worth BY ANY MEANS. People have value in many different ways beyond money output or production capability. BUT, this output capacity is directly related to our states of consciousness none the less. The more aware and consciousness we are, the greater our output is. My point, is that even though we all have lots of potential, many of us are squandering it. Compared to Elon, I'm a complete fool. And compared to me, that 20 dollar an hour person is a fool too. This illustrates how large of a dynamic spectrum we can occupy in our states of consciousness. I don't think we should feel bad about not super achieving, but I do think we should ask ourselves if we are selling ourselves short. If you asked me if that 20/hr person has value, I would say "of they course do, and their value is WAY higher than they think it is". I have sold myself short many times. So many of us have. Let's try to not do that anymore. Let's search for our TRUE potential, not the potential/labels we have put on ourselves, or the ones society has thrown on us.

The idea of a vehicle that drives itself but still needs safety features is counter productive. I think most people understand this and still buy AI powered cars as a support for the development for AI. True self driving cars will happen when every single vehicle on the road is driven by the same system. Current cities have roads that evolved from the carriage. We need cities that are, from the very beginning, built with the intent of supporting an entire system of automated transportation pods. Cities that from the beginning don't have stop signs or traffic lights. These pods will not even need safety features because they will all be operated by the same neural net. This neural net will be possible, and is dependent, on the development of computing power and connection speeds. All of this is already known by many but it's not worth breaking your head about it because all of this is not possible yet with current technology. It is also dependent on the desire of the consumers and public opinion. Who will want to live like this? Public persuasion goes hand in hand with the advancement of technology. In both of these aspects, humanity isn't there yet. Once humanity wants, and is able to, build a city, or modify an existing one, it will be because there are already millions lined up with the desire to live this way and willing to purchase a home in a city such as this. In this economy people won't actually own their vehicle anymore but whatever. I'd rather skip this part and go straight to drone transportation but maybe a middle step is needed in order for consumers to completely trust the neural network.

I wish Elon would have mentioned reducing mean/dairy consumption and eliminating food waste as a part of the gameplan. I understand he sells batteries and that's his focus. But we all need to start caring. According to a recent Oxford University study published in Science, food system emissions alone are eating up the world‚Äôs remaining carbon budget. To stay below the critical 2 degrees Celsius rise, we have only 1,500 gigatons of carbon dioxide equivalent left to emit by the end of the century. If we don't adopt mass dietary changes (and animal food productions is the biggest driver of climate change), food emissions alone will take up 1,356 gigatons, leaving no room for any other sectors--including Elon's energy sector hopes and dreams. I get that people love their burgers and many will want to delude themselves to keep eating them, but the science is really clear on this one. Americans are one of the worlds biggest meat consumers and also have the worst health among developed nations.

Here's my problem. I live in Kansas, traditionally one of the most authoritative Judeo-Christian Conservative states in the country. 42.2% of our energy was generated from wind turbines (built, run, and maintained in Kansas), only second to Iowa in the entire country. In fact, Kansas is the fourth most "green" state in the USA. Only 18.8% of the state's electricity was generated via coal, with the rest being a combination of nuclear, hydrothermal, geothermal, and natural gas. So you would think that Kansas has some of the cheapest electricity per kWh in the nation. Kansas doesn't. In fact, it's 10.2% higher than the national average, which is 29% higher than Oklahoma and 32% higher than Missouri per kWh. Evergy, which is the company that provides electricity to the bulk of Kansas, has consistently asked for increases every single year per kWh. They claim that this is due to "the costs associated with maintaining wind turbines" and "building additional wind turbines". The problem is that only 35% of Evergy's budget went to building new turbines, the rest was apparently "maintaining" the turbines.

Elon says that we are "on a good path" to avoid climate catastrophe, as long as we are not complacent, have a high sense of urgency, and push hard to stay on this path. The problem is, according to the IPCC, we are not "on a good path". After the most recent UN COP 25 conference on climate change an analysis was made for where the current PLEDGES (which we are far from meeting) made by the worlds governments would get us to on eliminating greenhouse gases and stopping the increase in global warming. This analysis said that with those pledges, we are currently on track for 2.5 to 3.0 degrees Celsius of warming, which would be catastrophic if that is where we end up. Warming needs to be stopped at 1.5 to 2.0 degrees Celsius to avoid this looming catastrophe, and decades of efforts to even PLEDGE to be on a path towards that have so far failed miserably. Needless to say with the ACTUAL efforts being made to eliminate greenhouse gases, we are on a path to well over 3.0 degrees Celsius of warming, and absolute devastation of our climate and ecosystem.

To me, regarding self driving cars, the most important thing is taking over my driving on long, inter-state hi-way journeys. This would allow me to sleep, read, and relax and let automation do it's job in a way that TRULY would affect my quality of life. Fifteen minute drives to work in the city I don't mind doing myself. The beauty is that interstate driving has the LEAST amount of AI variance required. It's those highly varied inner-city AI experiences that are EXTREMELY hard to model. So, with my philosophy I would not be surprised if we are not already there. Let's forget about complex inner-city driving, get the technology up and running for interstate travel, and then tweak the intra-city complexities later. Let's not delay implementing the most valuable part of the equation so that we can get it 100% right. One valuable, and usable step at a time.

Every social/economic system in mans history owes its creation, and eventual demise, to technology convergences. Events that fundamentally changed our relationship to our environments, and thus our society as a whole, because the human species is a behavioral product of its environment. It is this attribute that has allowed us to adapt to virtually every environment on earth. Every model has had a technological best before date. Our current system is based upon the presence of artificially created scarcity for profits today. It is not designed to solve problems. Its designed to perpetuate problems for profits. Because if you actually solve the issues of scarcity? There is no way to profit from it anymore. It will no longer function in a world of abundance. Labor (both physical and mental) is now adverse to productivity and efficiency in our digitally enabled reality. And even the programmers and engineers are not immune to the advancements in AI. We are already using them to cut workloads today.

If you really want to make a change in the climate, Elon, stop making expensive electric cars that people making minimum wage could never afford.  It can't be that hard to make a simple economy car that is less than $20k.  Most poor people can do without the luxury of electronics that don't directly control the car's motor. We choose which delusions we want to follow. Some delusions can be healthy, with positive potential, while others, destructive. It could be the delusion of fame and fortune, or that science will fix everything for us, or that we need law and religion to be ethical, or that you are god incarnate. Which delusions cage your mind and which free it? We think we know what is real, but it's all human social construct. One thing I feel is real is that we are not merely visitors here, not only part of this reality, we are in fact the universe, experiencing itself as individuals. Everything that exists adding its unique conscious perspective. The elements of our bodies were forged in the stars, yet our consciousness is somehow not our body. And how awesome it is to get the human experience! Allowing us to share in great detail our individual perspectives and experiences, being able to imagine the infinite potential we, as life on earth, have yet to realize. I follow this delusion and I choose to believe we will collectively understand that we as humanity, are the ones that choose the quality of our world. The only thing holding us back is ourselves. We can choose to doubt ourselves or to believe in our limitless potential. Our reality seems to bend toward what we think and express. So I choose to imagine and speak of a utopian future, all living things in harmony and balance, learning from the intelligence of evolution to advance and create ideas and technology to make life more enjoyable for all of us equally, to protect life from existential threats. I would much rather be a nobody in that world than a winner of this competitive world. We choose.

We live in a world where it's become toxic to talk about or even acknowledge failure, but one of the big secrets of humanity is that we learn by our mistakes and failures, get up, dust ourselves down and go again. It may take a hundred years to realise this dream, and he may have to pass on the baton to someone else to fully realise that dream, but that dream will become a reality.  I have more faith in EM's best guesses than the assurances and guarantees of any politician.

Low cost sustainability energy, I'm all for it. However as for personal robots.... Basically it will be like a personal PDA or our handphones right now but in a much larger and smarter mobile form that will actually service you and your family members. It will be like the good old Japanese anime - Chobits from 2000 ‚Äì 2002. The AI in the anime is just amazing. Or maybe even like iRobots the movie. But it is also a double edge sword with AI. If the real-world AI become so powerful and dynamic near to the human level, then why do we even need humans anymore? For a start, jobs will be outsourced to AI robots. How do humans even earn an honest living then? TBH, having a full AI controlled future is not too bright for the next generations. Stephen Hawking already warned us about exploiting too much into AI. Democratization of AI can never achieve as long as there are humans around. Politics and greed from countries and companies will always be there. Do we see Google, Apple, Microsoft or even Huawei exchanging and sharing their AI secrets? I would say, let's not cross the line of AI and resulting us, the humans, suffering from our own actions.

Compare this to the actions of DSC 37 112 Matthew Lindsay in Victoria Australia.  Lindsay incarcerated me for two summary charges, (i) failure to give my address at the time of arrest and (ii) unlicensed driving.  I have never been convicted or charged with either of these offences previously.  I pleaded not guilty so the Magistrate incarcerated me on remand even though I had an address, a job, a partner and a daughter.  I went to the Supreme Court of Victoria for bail and the Supreme Court Judge Justice Coghlin continued to remand me in custody - the highest court in the state - for refusing to give my residential address when arrested.  Justice Coghlin stated, and I quote directly, "You will not get bail from me until you give me that address."  I have the court transcripts.  I was remanded in custody for 22 months for 'failing to give my residential address when arrested'.  I was then bailed - after 22 months - on $50,000.00.  It is now nearly five years since  the charges.  I refuse to plead guilty and Lindsay DSC 37112 is still trying to convict me of 'failure to give my residential address when arrested'.

It is a travesty (though no surprise) that cop, Eric Parker, was not convicted.  It's a surprise a misbehaving cop was charged and prosecuted at all.  Though Parker may not have intended physical injury, he was unnecessarily aggressive and there was no legitimate reason to impose physical force on this innocent, inoffensive man.  He is responsible for the injury he caused.  The defense attorney's attempt to project blame on the victim through his statement that visitors to the U.S. are expected to "obey our laws and speak our language" was wrong on both counts and reflects not only his own attitude but widespread ignorance, arrogance, bigotry and xenophobia among our population.  That little, old man was clearly not violating any laws and there is no requirement either to speak or understand English in the U.S.  This is only one of a multitude of unpunished outrages committed by police officers in the U.S.  The "bad apples" among police are, and have always been, common and give the public ample cause to mistrust police.  Now we have cameras and video and bad cops are sometimes held to account, but not nearly often enough.  Kudos to these Alabama prosecutors for bringing this case to trial twice.  It's a shame they weren't successful in securing a conviction.
